Research Project
=====================================

Column {data-width=1}
-----------------------------------------------------------------------

###

<center><a href="https://www.elsevier.com/books/parking/pojani/978-0-12-815265-2" target="_blank"><img src="../data/book_cover.jpg" style="width:100%"/></a></center>

Column {data-width=2}
-----------------------------------------------------------------------

###
<p></p>
A significant portion of metropolitan land is allocated for parking private vehicles, which could be regarded an *unproductive* use of public, commercial, and private urban space given estimates that private vehicles are stationary 95% of the time (Button [2006]( https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0967070X06000436)) and four parking bays exist for every registered private vehicle (Cullinane, Smith, and Green [2004]( https://deepblue.lib.umich.edu/bitstream/handle/2027.42/87990/102765.pdf?sequence=1); Jakle and Sculle [2004]( https://books.google.com.au/books?hl=en&lr=&id=bV622ieCXakC&oi=fnd&pg=PP15&ots=cm-Dnd2ToO&sig=5upxqYTiHqwdo_amjBKMMlHdmnk&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q&f=false)). While unknown for Australia, Europe has an estimated 30,000 km^2^ of land allocated for parking and the United States 27,000 km^2^ with much of this parking located on valuable inner city land (Inci [2015](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2212012214000562)). Indeed, the cost of parking space can at times exceed the motor vehicle itself such as Sydney residential parking bays listed for 495,000AUD and auctioning for 120,000AUD (CarAdvice [2018](https://www.9news.com.au/motoring/sydney-car-parking-space-up-for-sale-for-almost-half-a-million/3d59cc98-2c8f-4d21-995b-6689cbd136cb)). This suggests that the public purchase off on-street and off-street parking has been immense and is essentially the public subsiding the private privilege to drive and park.
While most cities have already been transformed to accommodate private vehicles that are stationary, the future of metropolitan parking is uncertain given:

* declines in driving (e.g. fewer vehicle kilometres travelled; younger generations delaying they gain a drivers licence and purchase a private vehicle);

* changes in land-use policy and regulation (e.g. urban consolidation; transit oriented development; parking maximums replacing parking minimums policies; suburban shopping centres charging for parking);

* emerging vehicle-sharing arrangements (e.g. GoGet, Flexicar, Car Next Door and Uber); and

* disruptive technologies that are anticipated (e.g. autonomous and semi-autonomous vehicles).

Researchers, practitioners and policy makers require urgent clarity on how to manage parking and prepare for the future of urban mobility. Instead, parking is typically overlooked in research and uncritically oversupplied in practice, which is proving an unproductive use of urban land without improving urban mobility, and that inhibits urban consolidation attempts. The association between congestion and sprawl is widely known yet the association with parking is generally overlooked. As such, this research project has the following aims:

1. Examine how driving behaviours, planning initiatives/regulations, and car sharing technologies are influencing the supply, demand, and location of parking, and determine whether these vary between the three largest Australian cities i.e. Sydney, Melbourne, and Brisbane.

2. Understand how parking policy can influence modal choices and travel behaviours, and whether this influence varies between the three largest Australian cities.

3. Explore scenarios that take current mobility trends into account.

4. Develop land use and transport planning guidelines for reducing and repurposing existing parking.

Column {data-width=2}
-----------------------------------------------------------------------

###
<p></p>
Globalisation and urbanisation are densifying cities and heightening demand for urban space and at the same time, disruptive technologies are emerging that transform and diversify our modal choices e.g., micro-mobility, smart phone applications, ride-hailing and car-sharing services, and eventually autonomous vehicles. As such, practitioners and policy makers are required to move more people within less space, and clear pathways for a diversifying array of vehicle types through cities that have been transformed been transformed in recent history to prioritise private cars. Further, they must collaborate with or be tasked by government officials whose continued re-election could depend upon appeasing suburban residents that are *unable* or *unwilling* to relocate to inner cities or near public transport nodes. Decades of these conditions and appeasement has created a positive feedback loop of *auto-dependency* since private transport can be necessary for traversing sprawling urban forms that have been enlarged by parking, driveways, roads, highways, and flyovers. Further, active and public transport can be impractical and financially infeasible within suburban density, and unpalatable and potentially dangerous where it is necessary to wade through traffic congestion or between fast-moving vehicles.

Given estimates that private vehicles remain stationary 95% of the time (Button [2006](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0967070X06000436)), the large swathes of high-value urban space devoted to storing immobile automobiles has the potential for more productive public use such as pathways for active (i.e. walking and cycling) and public (i.e. riding buses, trams, ferries, and trains) transport that do not require parking. Further, the expectation of free or cheap parking is impedes urban mobility given that motorists will slowly cruise to locate vacant parking and further delay trailing traffic while manoeuvre into parking. As such, growing numbers of researchers are accusing practitioners and policy makers that prioritise private transport before active and public transport as *out-of-touch* with contemporary urban mobility trends such as younger generations of OECD adults that are delaying when they start driving. This particular trend suggests that expensive, polluting, dangerous private vehicles are losing the “instruments of freedom” status that was once ascribed by more senior members of the contemporary working population (Goodwin and van Dender [2013](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/01441647.2013.804133)). 

Irrespective the declining popularity of private transport can attributed towards worsening economic prospects or changing generational zeitgeist, it is also worth noting that disruptive transport technologies are emerging at an accelerating rate (e.g. ride-hailing, ride-sharing, micromobility, Mobility as a Service, and Autonomous Vehicles) in addition to what may be the *contemporary instruments of freedom* (e.g. the internet, smartphones, online shopping, applications, and services) that are replacing some social visits and are negating some journeys such as collecting takeaway food (e.g. Deliveroo) and entertainment (e.g. Netflix). These technologies are also minimising the *first mile problem* accessing rapid public transport from low-density suburban settings (e.g. Uber at Altamonte Springs; Comas [2016](https://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/seminole-county/os-altamonte-springs-uber-transportation-20160304-story.html)) and the *last mile problem* reaching the final destination from the nearest public transport node (e.g. Lime; Sipe and Pojani [2018]( https://theconversation.com/can-e-scooters-solve-the-last-mile-problem-theyll-need-to-avoid-the-fate-of-dockless-bikes-102633)). As such, prioritising private transport over the active and public alternatives may not only be out-of-touch but also burdening future generations with sprawling cities blanketed by artificial surfaces (Geels et al. [2011](https://www.routledge.com/Automobility-in-Transition-A-Socio-Technical-Analysis-of-Sustainable-Transport/Geels-Kemp-Dudley-Lyons/p/book/9780415885058)) and aging suburban, rural, and remote populations stranded in place (Bailey [2004](https://trid.trb.org/view/697686)). To avoid this scenario, researchers, practitioners, and policy makers have begun the task of identifying where parking could reclaimed and repurposed for docking-stations, protected bike lanes, and automobile drop-off lanes.

<button class="accordion">Who pays for free parking?</button>
<div class="panel">
<p></p>

In Shoup’s ([2011]( https://web.archive.org/web/20170224033309/http://shoup.bol.ucla.edu/Chapter1.pdf)) influential book entitled *The High Cost of Free Parking*, they make the case that *everyone* pays for *free parking* given that:

**Premise 1**: developers embed the marginal costs of fulfilling parking minimum standards into property leases and sales; 

**Premise 2**: merchants recuperate private overheads when pricing their goods and services; 

**Premise 3**: government departments recuperate public overheads through rates, registration, and taxes; and so, 

**Conclusion**: the public is subsidising the private privilege to drive or more precisely, private privilege to store private property at a convenient location.

In a later book, Shoup ([2018](https://www.routledge.com/Parking-and-the-City/Shoup/p/book/9781138497122?gclid=Cj0KCQiA9P__BRC0ARIsAEZ6irj032NOjygTEyrS7Ffs4zvWYPHQkPSiSiXZYIc0ykXVWCMJ-1bH940aAs84EALw_wcB)) estimated that there are at least three non-residential parking spaces for every registered vehicle in the United States thus further revealing the enormity this free parking privilege. Manville ([2017](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/01944363.2016.1249508)) adds that parking is a *shadow market* that has the hallmarks of the *rent control problem* (Arnott, 1995) since parking demand is potentially limitless and so increasing parking supply cannot fulfil demand. Further estimates suggest that mandatory parking requirements inflate the cost of residential renting by 10% in the United States, residential construction by between US$10,000 and US$14,000 in Seattle and by 10% in Stockholm, and shopping centre construction by 67% for above-ground parking and by 97 % for below-ground in Los Angeles (Shoup [2014](https://www.emerald.com/insight/content/doi/10.1108/S2044-994120140000005011/full/html); Andersson et al. [2016]( https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0967070X16302232), Gabbe and Pierce [2017](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/10511482.2016.1205647)). Given that everyone is purchasing or renting parking irrespective of whether they own a private vehicle, it could explain why services including [Parkhound](https://www.parkhound.com.au/), [Kerb](https://kerb.works/australia/brisbane), [Reef Technology](https://reeftechnology.com/), and [United Dwelling](https://www.uniteddwelling.com/adu/how-to-convert-a-garage-into-an-accessory-dwelling-unit) are emerging that enable landholders to lease unused parking for commercial parking, cloud-kitchens, and dwellings, which is an accelerating phenomena we term “bay-sharing” in the upcoming *The Modern Guide to the Urban Sharing Economy*.   

See Kimpton et al. ([2020](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.progress.2020.100506)) for further reading.
<p></p>
</div>

<button class="accordion">Parking Demand</button>
<div class="panel">
<p></p>
As previously discussed, parking demand is potentially limitless given that increasing parking supply also increases the convenience and appeal of driving. The Australian Bureau of Statistics’ (ABS) Census of Population and Housing ([2011; 2016](https://www.abs.gov.au/websitedbs/d3310114.nsf/home/2016%20datapacks)) reveals 2011, 2016, and changes between for inner Brisbane, Sydney, and Melbourne residential private vehicle ownership at the SA1-level and the workers arriving by private vehicles at the SA2-level (see Figure 1 below). With this data, it is possible to estimate residential off street parking demand and inner city worker parking demand (see Table 1).
<center><img src="../data/inner_city_pop.png" width="600" /> </center>
<center><b><i>Figure 1. Inner city residential (SA1) and worker (SA2) populations</i></b> (from Kimpton et al. <a href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.progress.2020.100506">2020</a>)</center>

<center><b><i>Table 1. Inner city parking demand</i></b> (from Kimpton et al. <a href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.progress.2020.100506">2020</a>)</center>
```{r DemandTable}
df1 <- read.csv("./../data/Demand.csv")
names(df1) <- c("Period:", "2011", "2016", "Change", "2011", "2016", "Change", "2011", "2016", "Change")
kable(df1) %>%
    add_header_above(c(" " = 1, "Brisbane" = 3,	"Sydney" = 3,	"Melbourne" = 3), bold = T) %>% 
  kable_classic() %>%
  kable_styling(full_width = F) %>%
  row_spec(0, bold = T)
```
<p></p>

For instance, inner Brisbane’s dwelling stock grew by 27% while car ownership grew by 26% thus remaining abreast of growth. In contrast, inner Sydney’s dwelling stock grew by 15% and inner Melbourne’s by 41% thus out-pacing car ownership that grew by 12% and 19% respectively. Further, inner Melbourne’s car-free dwellings grew by 61% thus greatly exceeding inner Brisbane and inner Sydney’s respective growth by 23% and 18%. Cumulatively, these findings suggest that inner Brisbane had the least success in managing parking demand, while inner Melbourne had the greatest success while improving the viability of living car-free. Further, inner Brisbane uniquely stood out as the only city where residential cars exceeded dwellings throughout the entire period.

Inner Brisbane and inner Melbourne’s populations grew by 47% and 45% respectively thus almost doubling inner Sydney’s 24% growth. Further, inner Brisbane residents driving private transport to work rose by 25% thus far exceeding inner Sydney and inner Melbourne’s respective rises of 6% and 11% thus suggesting residents arriving in inner Brisbane are retaining their suburban mobility habits. 

Examining inner city workers last reveals that inner Brisbane had 9% rise in inner city workers while inner Sydney and inner Melbourne had 26% and 22% respectively. Further, inner Brisbane workers arriving by private transport rose by 2% while inner Sydney and inner Melbourne declined by 3% and 5% respectively. These findings suggest that inner Sydney and inner Melbourne had greater success in concentrating workplaces within the inner city, which are generally locations more viable for arriving by public transport. This may explain why driving into the inner city is in decline for these two inner cities.

See Kimpton et al. ([2020](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.progress.2020.100506)) for further reading.
<p></p>
</div>

<button class="accordion">Parking Supply</button>
<div class="panel">
<p></p>
*Parking minimums* typically apply within land use policy to ensure developers supply enough parking to fulfil the parking demand predicted for a given land use. How these parking minimums were initially calibrated is unclear given that land use authorities rarely keep records of the pre-existing parking supply, and what exactly constitutes “predicted parking demand” is unclear given that it is potentially limitless (Shoup [2011]( https://web.archive.org/web/20170224033309/http://shoup.bol.ucla.edu/Chapter1.pdf)). Estimates suggest that if all on-street and off-street parking was laid flat for the typical United States city, it would blanket at least 10% of the total surface area (Scharnhorst, [2018](https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/4598972-RIHA-Parking-Report)) or as much as 30% in the case of Los Angeles County (Chester et al. [2015]( https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/01944363.2015.1092879)).

While comparable estimates for Australian cities have not been published prior, it is possible to calculate the recent parking supply rate for inner Brisbane, Sydney, and Melbourne by examining approved development applications (Table 2; Figure 2). Further, the City of Sydney and the City of Melbourne local governments periodically conduct a land use census for their respective Local Government Areas (LGAs), which include parking and enable calculation of the pre-existing parking supply for at least the inner city. In contrast, the Brisbane City Council (BCC) confirms that they do not conduct a comparable land use survey and only release paid on street parking data so it is not possible to observe free on street parking. Further, the BCC LGA is considerably larger than the City of Sydney and Melbourne LGAs and so the “inner city frame” from the 2014 Brisbane City [ePlan]( https://cityplan.brisbane.qld.gov.au/eplan/) is used to provide a comparable “inner city”, and off street parking can only be examined using a land use sample that is available upon request from Transport and Main Roads (TMR) that is the state transit authority (Table 2). Drawing upon these data, it is possible to compare inner Brisbane, Sydney, and Melbourne’s parking supply to typical United States city (see Kimpton et al. [2020]( https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0305900620300271?via%3Dihub)).

<center><b><i>Table 2. approved development applications that list residential parking</i></b> (from Kimpton et al. <a href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.progress.2020.100506">2020</a>)</center>
```{r DevelopmentApplicationTable}
df1 <- read.csv("./../data/DA.csv")
names(df1) <- c("", "Brisbane",	"Sydney",	"Melbourne")
kable(df1) %>%
  kable_classic() %>%
  kable_styling(full_width = F) %>% 
  footnote(general = "the Melbourne database does not distinguish parking types so these figures may include some commercial parking", general_title = "Note:", footnote_as_chunk = T) %>% 
  row_spec(0, bold = T)
```
<p></p>

Table 2 reveals that on average, parking supply exceeds dwelling supply as listed within development applications approved for inner Brisbane (e.g. 1.1 parking bays per dwelling), while the opposite is observed for inner Sydney and Melbourne (e.g. 0.67 and 0.76 respectively). While the recent parking supply rate is considerably higher for inner Brisbane, these parking supply rates are not perfectly comparable given that inner Brisbane development applications only available in an aggregated spatial unit that partially eclipses the BCC inner city frame by including suburbs such as Toowong and Milton. Likewise, the City of Melbourne development applications do not enable perfect comparability given that since residential and guest parking are combined.

<p></p>
<center><img src="../data/figure1.png" width="500" /> </center>
<center><b><i>Figure 2. average parking per dwelling on approved development applications</i></b> (from Kimpton et al. <a href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.progress.2020.100506">2020</a>)</center>
<p></p>

Figure 2 further highlights the distinction between inner Brisbane and the remaining inner cities given that just 6 out of 61 inner Brisbane development applications are located below the y-line at 1 that signifies “unbundled parking” since there is not enough parking for every dwelling. Notably, the BCC inner city frame is predominately zoned by a *parking maximums* policy that restricts parking supply to 1 bay per 1 or 2 bedroom dwelling. As such, having the majority of approved development applications located above the y-line located at one suggest either weak policy enforcement or that majority of residential development features at least 3 bedrooms which raised the parking maximums above 1. In contrast, 46 out of 49 inner Sydney development applications, and 30 out of 42 for inner Melbourne development applications are located below the y-line located at 1 thus suggesting that these cities are stronger enforcers of parking maximums, and so parking can be purchased as required rather than as mandated by traditional *parking minimums*. In sum, inner Brisbane’s recent parking supply rate exceeds the inner Sydney and Melbourne by a large margin which may explain earlier findings that vehicle ownership and driving to work are on the rise from inner Brisbane.

Having examined the recent parking supply *rate* for residential development, turning to Table 3 reveals the *known* parking supply for comparability with the typical US city. Notably, the inner Melbourne census is used to impute data absent from the inner Sydney census and inner Brisbane sample given that inner Melbourne is the only city that measures area and counts parking bays.

<center><b><i>Table 3. the known inner city parking supply</i></b> (from Kimpton et al. <a href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.progress.2020.100506">2020</a>)</center>
```{r SupplyTable}
df1 <- read.csv("./../data/Supply.csv")
names(df1) <- c("", "Brisbane",	"Sydney",	"Melbourne")
kable(df1) %>%
  kable_classic() %>%
  kable_styling(full_width = F) %>% 
  row_spec(0, bold = T) %>% 
  pack_rows("Counted", 1, 9) %>%
  pack_rows("Derived", 10, 17)
```
<p></p>

The BCC parking data reveals that inner Brisbane contains 883 parking meters and 6,924 paid on street parking bays, and the TMR sample reveals that 18 percent of the inner Brisbane surface was sampled and that inner Brisbane contains *at least* 60,014 off street parking bays, which includes residential, commercial, and workplace parking. Combining these parking data with the ABS’ parking demand data (returning to Table 2) reveals that only 1 in 4.6 inner Brisbane private vehicles has a known off street parking, and 1 in 1.6 private vehicles that are arriving with inner city workers. With average parking bay sizes derived from the City of Melbourne parking data, inner Brisbane contains at least 1,928 hectares of parking that could cover at least 5 percent of inner city surface if laid flat. Notably, this coverage is already exceptionally high by international standards given that it does not include *free* on-street parking or the 82 percent of inner Brisbane buildings not included within the TMR sample.

The City of Sydney parking data reveals inner Sydney contains 1,365 parking meters and 20,897 paid on street parking bays thus twice inner Brisbane known supply. Unlike the BCC parking data, the City of Sydney parking census includes off street parking so it possible to provide a relatively accurate estimate that inner Sydney contains 11,959 residential and 5,919 other off street parking bays. Drawing upon ABS’ parking demand data once more reveals only 1 in 5.13 private vehicles have known off street residential parking, and just 1 in 20.99 private vehicles arriving with inner Sydney workers. Again imputing average parking bay size from the City of Melbourne parking data, inner Sydney contains at least 50.132 hectares of parking that could cover 5 percent of the inner city surface if laid flat. Similar to inner Brisbane, this estimate does not include free on street parking and ABS 2016 parking demand data suggests that the inner Sydney census is incomplete.

Last, the City of Melbourne parking data provides the most comprehensive coverage of inner city parking. Specifically, there are 23,310 on-street parking bays with 2,928 of these managed by 1,962 parking meters and 3,111 by on street sensors that connect to a smart phone application and enable motorists to pay by the minute rather than their predicted duration. Further, the City of Melbourne on street parking data is polygonal rather than point or tabular data so it is possible to calculate that there is 33.95 hectares of on-street parking. For off-street parking, there are 49,371 known residential off street parking bays and 143,740 other off street parking bays. Against the ABS parking demand data, reveals that there are 1.43 (i.e. 1/0.7) residential parking bays known for every inner Melbourne private vehicle thus suggesting a residential parking oversupply. In contrast, there are 1.05 cars arriving with inner Melbourne workers for each other off street parking bay that is known thus suggesting either an incomplete census, a sudden drop in private vehicle ownership, or a classification error between private and other parking. Finally, the parking data reveals that there are 207.83 hectares of residential parking known, 157.28 hectares of other off-street parking known,  and 33.95 hectares of on street parking known thus it is possible to provide a relatively estimate that all known parking could cover 11%of inner Melbourne if laid flat. As such, the inner Melbourne 11%  estimate is similar to the typical US city 10% estimate (Scharnhorst, [2018](https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/4598972-RIHA-Parking-Report)). 

See Kimpton et al. ([2020](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.progress.2020.100506)) for further reading.
<p></p>
</div>

<button class="accordion">Parking Management</button>
<div class="panel">
<p></p>
Given that parking demand is potentially limitless, councils are switching increasing from the *predict and provide* approach towards a *demand management* approach to parking to ensure that the user pays at least portion of the cost for parking. While *paid parking* and *parking fines* are frequently interpreted as “revenue raising” by councils in media (e.g. Hurst [2010](https://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/national/queensland/a-fine-way-to-raise-27-million-20100609-xwae.html); O’Sullivan and Gladstone [2019]( https://www.smh.com.au/national/nsw/parking-fines-reap-sydney-councils-650m-in-four-years-20190912-p52qll.html); or Becker [2020]( https://9now.nine.com.au/a-current-affair/coronavirus-melbourne-parking-inspectors-still-handing-out-infringements-as-city-enters-stage-four-covid19-restrictions/f87adc4d-74a0-465a-9917-4f1e9b79aee8)), which is an interpretation that disregards the public cost and value of urban *space* purchased for storing private transport while it is immobile and therefore unproductive. Further, this interpretation assumes that individuals have an intrinsic right to driving and convenient parking rather than the reality that driving is one of many *modal choices* available within metropolitan areas. Table 1 reveals how much inner Brisbane, Sydney, and Melbourne motorists are paying for their parking.

<p></p>
<center><b><i>Table 4. average inner city parking prices</i></b> (from Kimpton et al. <a href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.progress.2020.100506">2020</a>)</center>
```{r PricingTable}
df1 <- read.csv("./../data/Pricing.csv")
names(df1) <- c("", "Brisbane",	"Sydney",	"Melbourne")
kable(df1) %>%
  kable_classic() %>%
  kable_styling(full_width = F) %>% 
  row_spec(0, bold = T) %>% 
  pack_rows("On-Street", 1, 2) %>%
  pack_rows("Off-Street", 3, 6) %>% 
  pack_rows("Overseas residential annual permit(average)", 7, 11)
```
<p></p>

From the lowest to highest parking rates, inner Sydney charges AU$3.70 per hour on average at parking meters, inner Brisbane AU$4.40, and inner Melbourne AU$5.50. Notably, metered-parking is generally not intended for long-stays such as nearby workers or park `n’ ride commuters but rather,  short-visits yet even inner-Melbourne’s AU$5.50 per hour would be priced below the general market-rate of inner Melbourne space. This begs the question are councils truly “revenue raising” or would “under-charging motorists” be a more accurate interpretation?

Examining parking permits next, inner Brisbane charges AU$10.00 per annum while inner Melbourne charges AU$30.00 and inner Sydney AU$53.00. In contrast to metered-parking, parking permits are generally intended to cover administrative charges of providing parking at locations developed without parking e.g. historical areas. Parking permits also vary considerably when examining just five overseas examples by ranging from AU$100.00 per annum for Manhattan Island, NY to AU$425.00 for the centre of Amsterdam. Nonetheless, these overseas parking permits greatly exceed the costs of Australian parking permits but still fail to recuperate the market value of inner city space.

In contrast to metered-parking and residential permits, commercial off street parking can provide a closer estimate of the true market rate of parking by revealing how much motorists are willing to pay where *free* or potentially *under-priced* public parking and workplace parking are not options. Inner Melbourne motorists on average will pay AU$20.56 per hour for short-visits, while inner Brisbane and Sydney motorists will pay more at AU$28.32 and AU$28.08 respectively. Interestingly, the minimum monthly cost for off-street parking is similar for the three inner cities although inner Melbourne’s maximum at AU$770.00 in considerably lower than inner Brisbane’s AU$953.00 and inner Sydney’s AU$1,099.00 thus suggesting either a parking oversupply in Melbourne so there is less market scarcity or that the motorists value parking less possibly due to better alternatives.

See Kimpton et al. ([2020](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.progress.2020.100506)) for further reading.
<p></p>
</div>

Column {data-width=2}
-----------------------------------------------------------------------

###
<p></p>
Planning policy and particularly parking policy can be a potent tool for influencing modal choice given parking determines *when*, *where*, and *whether* driving is a convenient and cost-effective modal choice (Manville [2017]( https://www.scopus.com/record/display.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85008462136&origin=inward)). Notably, land use policy is typically the domain of local councils while transport policy is typically the domain of state government. As a consequence, metropolitan land use planning is often fragmented between multiple local councils and so *policy inequalities* can emerge. For example, an outer city council may introduce a Transit Orientated Development (TOD) policy to concentrate residential development within a walkable range of rapid public transport nodes while an inner city local government may introduce a parking minimums policy to increase inner city parking supply and attract commerce (Young and Miles [2015]( https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2213624X14000297)). In this scenario, the inner city council is undermining the outer city council’s attempt to encourage commuters to park ‘n’ ride by increasing the convenience of parking in the inner city. While poor coordination between councils can emerge as fragment land use planning when the metropolitan system is considered, policy inequalities also emerge between the local land use authorities and the state transport authority given that the state often is relegated to a *responsive role* to the fragmented land use planning rather than *prescriptive* role of developing an efficient metropolitan transport system (Barter [2015](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/12265934.2014.927740)).

Parking policy can occupy a complex policy space wedge between council land use policies and the state transport policies yet it is a potent policy space given that private transport journeys begin and end in parking. Practitioners and policy makers will typically adopt one of three distinct planning approaches to parking: (1) ‘predict and provide’, (2) ‘multimodalism’, or (3) ‘demand management’ and these planning approaches can be arranged along a pragmatist-radical continuum according to its potential to *agitate* or *appease* the voters of elected leaders (Shoup [2011]( https://web.archive.org/web/20170224033309/http://shoup.bol.ucla.edu/Chapter1.pdf); Table 5).

<center><b><i>Table 5. A comparative framework of urban mobility organised by planning orientation, approach, and intended modal choice</i></b> (from Kimpton et al. <a href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.progress.2020.100506">2020</a>)</center>

```{r PolicyAimsTable}
df1 <- read.csv("./../data/PolicyAims.csv")
names(df1) <- c("Orientation", "Approach", "Residential", "Workplace", "Transport", "Link 1",  "Link 2",  "Link 3",  "Link 4", "First Mile", "Last Mile")
kable(df1) %>%
  kable_classic() %>%
  add_header_above(c("Planning" = 2, "Location" = 2,  "Modal" = 5, "Problem" = 2), bold = T) %>% 
  row_spec(3:5, background = "#F0F0F0") %>% 
  kable_styling(full_width = F) %>% 
  row_spec(0, bold = T)
```

See Kimpton et al. ( [2020](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.progress.2020.100506)) for further reading.

<button class="accordion">Predict & Provide</button>
<div class="panel">
<p></p>

The predict and provide planning approach has dominated parking planning for at least the last fifty years (Goulden, Ryley, and Dingwall [2014](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0967070X14000213)). It is particularly *pragmatic* in that it accepts that some if not most commuters already reside within auto-dependent locations (i.e. where private automobiles are necessary) and avoids agitating the public by *predicting* parking demand, and *providing* parking accordingly. Providing entails ensuring there is enough parking at home, work, and regularly visited locations (e.g. supermarkets and services) so that all private transport arriving during the peak-demand period could feasibly park off street (i.e. ‘parking self-containment’). The aim is to prevent parking *overflow* into public on street parking and neighbouring off street parking, which can become a source of social conflict. Further, the aim is to provide *enough* parking so that a portion of parking remains vacant to minimise cruising periods that will slow all trailing traffic (Seibert [2008](https://www.cis.org.au/app/uploads/2015/04/images/stories/policy-magazine/2008-winter/24-2-2008-christian-seibert.pdf)). Barter ( [2015](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/12265934.2014.927740); Table 6) adds that the ‘mindsets’ of parking providers can vary according to whether they regard parking as a *market good* (e.g. the user pays for the modal choice and its parking requirements) or *public infrastructure* (e.g. parking is market failure yet a universal right so the government must intervene), and whether they intend to manage parking at the site or district level.

<center><b><i>Table 6. three parking-based mindsets </i></b> (from Barter<a href="https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/12265934.2014.927740">2015</a>)</center>

```{r MindsetTable}
df1 <- read.csv("./../data/Mindsets.csv")
names(df1) <- c("", "District-Emphasis", "Site-Emphasis")
kable(df1) %>%
  kable_classic() %>%
  kable_styling(full_width = F) %>%
  row_spec(0, bold = T) %>% 
  column_spec(1, bold = T, border_right = T) %>% 
  column_spec(2, border_right = T)
```
<p></p>

Specific predict and provide approaches can include ensuring parking is provided at destinations so that *private transport* is a viable modal choice. This approach the most likely to appease the public since they will not encounter the *first mile* problem of reaching public transport from their home or encounter the *last mile* problem of reaching their destination from their last public transport stop. Another specific predict and provide approach can include providing enough *direct public transport* coverage so that public transport provides efficiency and convenience that is comparable to private transport. Unfortunately for sprawling cities that have prioritised private transport for decades, the public expense of providing a comprehensive public transport network throughout suburbia and regular services to provide convenience comparable to private transport can be financially infeasible. As such, compromises need to be made which can leave many with the first and last mile problems of public transport and so private transport retains its greater appeal.    
Predict and provide policies will typically specify *parking minimums* that developers must fulfil to ensure that all predicted vehicles predicted to arrive during peak demand periods can park on site (Shoup [1999](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0965856499000075)). For example, the 2014 Brisbane City Plan (Brisbane City Council [2014]( https://cityplan.brisbane.qld.gov.au/eplan/#Rules/0/274/1/14207/0)) specifies parking minimums that require: bars to have at least 6 parking bays per 100 m2 gross floor area; hospitals at least 0.5 parking bays per bed and 0.8 per staff member; and district parks to have between 10 and 20 parking bays. Critics argue that the *calibration* of parking minimums typically lacks a rigorous evidence base (Andersson [2016](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0967070X16302232); Shoup [1999](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0965856499000075); Millard-Ball [2015](https://www.jtlu.org/index.php/jtlu/article/view/384)) and is generally the *ad nauseam* reproduction of the US Institute of Transportation Engineers’ 1987 *Trip Generation Manual* adjusted for local land use definitions (Shoup [2006](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0967070X06000448)). Further, each parking bay needs to be scaled to accommodate the largest domestic vehicle size, which has resulted in parking oversupply in terms of the urban space it consumes. Marsden ( [2006](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0967070X06000412)) adds that *parking minimums* frequently burdened households with surplus parking by failing to discriminate between those: (a) intending to own multiple private vehicles; (b) choosing live auto-free; or (c) unable to afford a private vehicle. This may explain the recent rise of ‘bay sharing’ services (e.g. Parkhound and Kerb) that enable car-free households to recuperate at least a portion of this economic burden (see Kimpton and colleagues forthcoming chapter in *The Guide to the Modern Sharing Economy*).

See Kimpton et al. ( [2020](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.progress.2020.100506)) for further reading.
<p></p>
</div>

<button class="accordion">Multimodalism</button>
<div class="panel">
<p></p>

Relative to predict and provide, a *multimodalism* planning approach is *radical* since it prioritises *rapid public transport* before *direct public transport* or *private transport* that can travel more direct routes thus there is greater potential for agitating the public (Table 5). Notably, this planning approach also shares some *pragmatist* leanings since it accepts that some already reside within low-density residential areas where their private vehicles are a convenient, flexible, and generally unimpeded modal choice. As such, the overarching multimodalism aim is to minimise *route redundancy* between motorists by sharing public transport and in so doing, reducing their collective demands for road capacity. By minimising route redundancy, this will also reduce their collective demands for expensive inner city parking space and collective Vehicle Kilometres Travelled (VKT) thus minimising the environmental impacts of urban mobility (Kimpton et al. [2020a](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.progress.2020.100506)). Notably, multimodalism approaches typically prioritise rapid public transport because although accessing this rapid services can impose lateral travel toward the destination, rapid public transport can be an appealing modal choice by providing commuters with priority pathways past inner city traffic congestion (e.g. Bus Rapid Transit, ferries routes, and train tracks; Ison and Mulley [2014](https://books.google.com.au/books?hl=en&lr=&id=uP5lBAAAQBAJ&oi=fnd&pg=PP1&ots=qABLnNLSZl&sig=-GPy9F42ntCBVei4Kr-SQGh5kys&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q&f=false); Parkhurst and Meek [2014](https://www-emerald-com.ezproxy.library.uq.edu.au/insight/content/doi/10.1108/S2044-994120140000005020/full/html); Meek et al. [2011](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0967070X10001150)). 

Specific multimodalism approaches can include the more pragmatic *intermodal* approach where parking (e.g., park ‘n’ rides) and/or drop off lanes (e.g., kiss ‘n’ rides) are provided at rapid transit nodes so that private transport can solve the first mile problem of public transport. In contrast, specific approaches such as the more radical *transmodal* approach require commuters to use *feeder public transport* to reach the rapid transit node. The advantage of feeder public transport for service providers is that these services can loop in greater frequency and avoid becoming locked within inner city traffic congestion. In contrast, feeder public transport may be relatively unappealing to those owning a car given that each additional *link* in a public transport journey introduces uncertainties and the amount *slack time* required each day in the event of service delays (Kimpton [2020b](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0264837719306246); Figure 1).

<center><img src="../data/Slack.png" width="600" /> </center>

<center><b><i>Figure 3. a framework of modal choice and reliability</i></b> (from Kimpton et al. <a href="https://doi.org/10.1016/J.LANDUSEPOL.2019.104304">2020</a>)</center>
<p></p>
For example, *capacity unreliability* is the potential for parking lots and public transport to be fully occupied upon arrival, *travel time unreliability* is the variability of public transport travel (e.g. accidents, breakdowns, traffic congestion, road works etc.), and *connectivity unreliability* is missed connections on account of the previous unreliabilities and result in further delays. Notably, public transport typically travels along a fixed route while private transport can be re-routed around obstacles and public transport is particularly vulnerable obstacles and introducing uncertainties. Last, it is notable that multimodalism approaches do not necessarily address the last mile problem of traveling from the rapid transit terminal to the destination given that public transport is involved, and so the magnitude of this problem can determine who chooses private transport and who chooses the intended *intermodal* or *transmodal* travel behaviours.

See Kimpton et al. ( [2020a](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.progress.2020.100506); [ 2020b](https://doi.org/10.1016/J.LANDUSEPOL.2019.104304) and Kimpton [2019](https://doi.org/10.1177/0308518X19890871);
[2020](https://doi.org/10.1007/s12061-020-09361-4)) for further reading. 
<p></p>
</div>

<button class="accordion">Demand Management</button>
<div class="panel">
<p></p>

Although the predict and provide approach remains the default parking approach in most urban settings, the *demand management* is steadily gaining popularity with researchers, practitioners, and policy makers raising concerns that demand for road capacity and parking are *potentially limitless*. Further, there is an expanding acceptance that active and public transport can minimise road capacity requirements and parking demand at popular locations where urban space is typically most expensive. The demand management approach is more *radical* than the predict and provide and the multimodalism approaches given that access to better urban mobility is requires relocating into higher urban density to keep active and public transport economically viable. As such, the lifestyle change this entails has greater potential to agitate the voting public that is *unable* or *unwilling* depart from their suburban lifestyle and the convenience and flexibility of private transport.

Specific demand management approaches include the *transit orientated* approach that concentrate residential development within walkable distance of rapid public transport nodes. A “walkable distance” is typically regarded somewhere between 250 and 800 meters (Singh et al. [2017]( https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0967070X16302505)), and generally resembles either single-node, multi-node, or corridor Transit Orientated Development (TOD) patterns (Table 7; Pojani and Stead [2016](https://www.scopus.com/record/display.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84994865493&origin=inward)). Within these walkable neighbourhoods, private transport is unnecessary for solving the first mile problem of accessing rapid public transport although it is notable that the last mile problem remains. In contrast, specific approaches such as the *24-hour city* approach concentrates residential and commercial development within walkable distance so residents may reside, shop, and work within the same neighbourhood. Through walkable and human-scale development, the aim is for public transport—or moreover motorised transport—to be unnecessary for most residents. This specific approach is particularly *radical* given that requiring the public to move away from suburbia and near their workplace to improve their urban mobility has the greatest potential for agitating the public.
<p></p>
<center><b><i>Table 7. types of Transit Orientated Development </i></b> (Pojani and Stead <a href="https://www.scopus.com/record/display.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84994865493&origin=inward">2016</a>)</center>
```{r TODTypesTable}
df1 <- read.csv("./../data/TodType.csv")
names(df1) <- c("TOD Type", "Characteristics")
kable(df1) %>%
  kable_classic() %>%
  kable_styling(full_width = F) %>% 
    row_spec(5:10, background = "#F0F0F0") %>% 
  column_spec(1, bold = T) %>% 
  row_spec(0, bold = T)
```
<p></p>
Demand management policies typically specify *parking restrictions* (e.g. parking signs, meters, and permits) and *parking maximums* policies (e.g. 1 or fewer parking spaces per dwelling) so that active and public transport gain greater appeal and convenience over private transport. Parking restrictions can be a controversial approach for councils since approach is frequently interpreted as “revenue raising” (e.g. Hurst [2010](https://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/national/queensland/a-fine-way-to-raise-27-million-20100609-xwae.html); O’Sullivan and Gladstone [2019]( https://www.smh.com.au/national/nsw/parking-fines-reap-sydney-councils-650m-in-four-years-20190912-p52qll.html); or Becker [2020](https://9now.nine.com.au/a-current-affair/coronavirus-melbourne-parking-inspectors-still-handing-out-infringements-as-city-enters-stage-four-covid19-restrictions/f87adc4d-74a0-465a-9917-4f1e9b79aee8)). On one Australian occasion, a councillor was attacked from behind at a public forum for introducing parking meters, and an intervening councillor was almost strangled by an enraged trader fearing that the meters reduce their customers (ABC News [2015]( https://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-11-18/punches-thrown-in-dispute-over-yarraville-parking-meters/6950128)). If their customers started visiting traders away from parking meters, then this would be an example of policy inequality however if parking meters are introduced everywhere, then presumably all traders can anticipate greater parking turnover and the resultant flow of customers. Given the knee-jerk reactions to parking restrictions, Shoup ([2018]( https://www.dropbox.com/s/6tg317xssltiddp/ParkingAndTheCity.pdf?dl=0)) advises councils to directly reinvest parking revenue into nearby amenities and streetscapes so that parking restrictions can be palatable for local stakeholders. There have been multiple approaches to paid parking restrictions including increasing rates near popular destinations to disperse parking demand into nearby low demand areas (Arnott and Rowse [1999](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0094119098920848)) and increasing the initial rate to encourage longer stays to minimise turnover, cruising, and manoeuvring associated with short stays and generates congestion (Glazer and Niskanen 1992). Also, Shoup’s ( [2006](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0967070X06000448)) demand-responsive parking is rapidly gaining popularity since parking meters are digitally linked and calibrated for a market equilibrium that keeps 20% parking vacancy on a given street. While this approach forces individuals to competitively bid for parking and therefore could potentially exclude the poorest household from high demand areas, it is notable that this 20% vacancy market equilibrium has reduced the average parking rate by 5% (Pierce and Shoup [2013]( https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/01944363.2013.787307)) while also dispersing parking demand away from popular destinations and reducing cruising for parking. Interestingly, Los Angeles, CA introduced an employee cash out policy where employees can request the annual value of their workplace parking in lieu of receiving workplace parking, which is increasing car-pooling and public transport ridership within workplaces (Christiansen et al. [2017]( https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2352146517306737)).

Demand management policies that specify parking maximums are intended to reduce the number of household cars (e.g. 1 parking space maximum per dwelling) or to *unbundle* parking from land purchases (e.g. 0.8 parking spaces per dwelling) so that parking can be purchased separately and as *needed* (Martens [2005]( http://www.transportation.org.il/sites/default/files/pirsum/martens-2005---effects-of-restrictive-parking-policy_0.pdf); Guo and Ren [2013]( https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/0042098012460735)). In this sense, unbundled parking exposes the market value of parking space so that households are better-informed when deciding about *how many or if any* private vehicles are a rational choice. Despite this intention, guest and public on street parking often enable residents to circumvent this demand management approach, and so this resultant *parking overspill* frequently becomes a source of body corporate and public conflict (Taylor [2014](http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/14649357.2014.929727)). As such, parking restrictions and parking maximums need to carefully coordinated to avoid policy inequality and social conflict.

Parking maximums zones are typically located in the inner city and at TOD yet cities including Buffalo City, NY, and Mexico City are among the first to introduce blanket polices that span the cities and reduce the potential for policy inequalities (Poon 2017; Schmitt 2017). Interestingly, Zurich has capped the city’s overall parking supply to the 1990 parking supply (McCahill and Garrick [2014]( https://www.emerald.com/insight/content/doi/10.1108/S2044-994120140000005017/full/html)), and San Francisco, CA introduced *parking minimums* for shared vehicle services where *parking maximums* apply so that residents giving up private vehicles retain access to the convenience and flexibility of driving (Ter Schure, Napolitan, and Hutchinson [2012](https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.3141/2319-11)).  

See Kimpton et al. ( [2020](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.progress.2020.100506)) for further reading.
<p></p>
</div>

<button class="accordion">An Integrative Approach</button>
<div class="panel">
<p></p>

As the multimodalism and demand management approaches gain popularity, practitioners and policy makers are left with the challenge of coordinating multiple approaches to ensure they are improving urban mobility at the metropolitan level. As discussed previously, policy inequalities can emerge *between local councils* and *with the state government* but what has not been discussed is that policy inequalities can also emerge *within local councils*. For instance, a council that attempts both a multimodalism and demand management approach to a single rapid transit node can find that the park ‘n’ ride traffic is reducing the walkability of the TOD zone, while the TOD raises local land values thus expanding the park ‘n’ ride facility may become financially infeasible (Willson [2005](https://scholarcommons.usf.edu/jpt/vol8/iss5/5/); Weinberger [2012]( https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0967070X11001028)). Further, the park ‘n’ ride facility could persuade the TOD residents to drive rather than walk and so the facility becomes exhausted by TOD residents rather than auto-dependent outsiders (Dovey et al. [2015]( https://search.informit.org/doi/10.3316/INFORMIT.968868422652829); Ginn [2009]( https://eprints.qut.edu.au/31827/1/Simon_Ginn_Thesis.pdf)). As such, an integrative model of modal choice is required for coordinating council policies at the metropolitan scale and minimising policy inequality by mapping the key spatial relationships (Figure 2; Kimpton et al. [2020]( https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0264837719306246)). For instance, Break Even Distances (BED) that reveal important thresholds for modal choices such as where the time saved by driving is outweighed by the time lost locating parking (i.e. the walk BED), and where the time saved by rapid public transport is outweighed by the time lost diverting the commuting route towards the rapid transit corridor (i.e. the park ‘n’ ride BED). Further BED include the point by which comprehensive feeder and rapid transit coverage becomes feasible due heightening residential density and where inner city park ‘n’ ride facilities could tempt motorist to ‘railhead’ rather than minimise their VKT by using their nearest to home (i.e. destination BED; Kimpton [2020](https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s12061-020-09361-4)).

<center><img src="../data/bed_and_sheds.png" width="600" /> </center>
<center><b><i>Figure 2. An intergrative model of modal choice</i></b> (from Kimpton et al. <a href="https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0264837719306246">2020</a>)</center>

See Kimpton et al. ([2020a](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.progress.2020.100506); [2020b]( https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0264837719306246)) for further reading.
<p></p>
</div>

<button class="accordion">Template Analysis</button>
<div class="panel">
<p></p>
*Template analysis* is a clear, systematic, and flexible qualitative method for summarising and contrasting large volumes of policy documentation to examine *whether* and *how* planning approaches towards parking have changed for Brisbane, Sydney, and Melbourne (King, [2012](http://sk.sagepub.com/books/qualitative-organizational-research-core-methods-and-current-challenges/i1774.xml)). For this application, 39 council and state policies for the three cities from 2000 to 2018 period organised according to the comparative framework of urban mobility (Table 5) with the *predict and provide* approach functioning as the baseline planning approach. Further, the *park ‘n’ ride* approach unambiguously signifies the multimodalism planning approach, while the *parking maximums*, *pricing*, and *transit orientated development* approaches signify the demand management planning approach.

<center><b><i>Table 8. template analysis of Brisbane, Sydney, and Melbourne policies</i></b> (Kimpton et al. <a href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.progress.2020.100506">2020</a>)</center>

```{r PolicyAnalysisTable}
df1 <- read.csv("./../data/PolicyAnalysis.csv")
names(df1) <- c("Year", "Policy",	"PnR", "Parking Maximums",	"Pricing",	"TOD")
kable(df1) %>%
  kable_classic() %>%
  add_header_above(c(" " = 2, "Multimodalism" = 1,  "Demand Management" = 3), bold = T) %>% 
  kable_styling(full_width = F) %>% 
  column_spec(2, italic = T) %>%
  pack_rows("Brisbane", 1, 12) %>%
  pack_rows("Sydney", 13, 28, background = "#F0F0F0") %>%
  pack_rows("Melbourne", 29, 39) %>%
  row_spec(0, bold = T) %>%  
  row_spec(13:28, background = "#F0F0F0") 
```

<p></p>

This analysis reveals that Brisbane, Sydney, and Melbourne all have policies that suggest a gradual transition from the predict and provide approach towards the multimodalism and demand management approaches. This strategic realignment suggests these cities are attempting to improve urban mobility by: (1) developing public and active transport as alternatives to private transport to relieve auto-dependency; (2) concentrating residential development within walking distance of rapid transit nodes to further relieve auto-dependency; (3) restricting parking supply to reduce the appeal of private transport; (4) charging motorists for the privilege of convenient public parking so that individuals can weigh this cost when making their modal choices; and (5) developing park `n’ rides so that the auto dependent have the option to can access rapid public transit rather than contribute towards inner city traffic congestion. 

Among these three cities and 39 policies, Melbourne is the earliest to implement a multimodalism planning approach in 2002 by recommending park 'n’ rides along rapid transport corridors. Brisbane later in 2008 followed with a more nuanced approach by recommending TOD zoning around rapid transit nodes located within 10km of the CBD and therefore a demand management approach, and park 'n’ ride facilities at the remaining rapid transit nodes and therefore a multimodalism approach. Notably, all three cities have policies recommending nodal- and corridor-based TOD (Table 7) although it is notable that the specific term ‘TOD’ only began appearing within recent policies.

Regarding parking restrictions, Sydney was the earliest to introduce parking maximums in 1991 with Brisbane and Melbourne following a decade later. All three cities have policies attributing parking oversupply to earlier predict and provide planning approaches. Further, all three cities have policies advising pragmatic reductions in inner city parking supply out of concern that radical reductions could stunt inner city economic growth and disperse economic activity away from the inner city.

Contrasting the three cities further reveals that Brisbane and Melbourne policies typically have parking requirements that vary according to a comprehensive list of distinct land use types and according to proximity to the CBD thus suggesting prescriptive, one-size-fits-all approach towards parking requirements. In contrast, Sydney polices typically distinguish between just a few key land use types thus suggesting a more adaptive, bespoke approach towards parking requirements. Interestingly, Sydney policies uniquely propose caps for residential parking permits, while Brisbane policies uniquely propose unbundled parking. Melbourne policies are the earliest to recommend that motorists pay fair market prices for parking space to reduce the appeal of private transport in 2002, and Brisbane and Sydney later provide similar recommendations in 2009 and 2010, respectively. Further, Melbourne polices take this fair market pricing idea one step further by discussing the demand responsive pricing approach. In sum, this template analysis of 39 policy documents suggests that the predict and provide planning approach and to a lesser extent, the multimodalism planning approach are falling out of favour as all three cities increasingly adopt the demand management approach for improving urban mobility.

See Kimpton et al. ( [2020](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.progress.2020.100506)) for further reading.

<p></p>
</div>

### Inner Brisbane, Queensland, Australia

<center><img src="../data/river-aerial_4_3_400w.jpg" width="100%" /> </center>

<center><p><b><i>The Brisbane River (<a href="https://grahamnunn.wordpress.com/tag/aerial-view-of-brisbane-river/">Nunn</a>)</i></b></p></center>

An aspiring ‘new world city’, Brisbane is located in the south-eastern corner of the State of Queensland, about 20 kilometres inland from the Pacific Ocean. The city spreads linearly along the snaking Brisbane River. Population densities are relatively low, and detached, single-family houses typify the built environment. However, the population is growing, and the inner city has recently experienced some high-rise development and densification. In conjunction with migration, the Brisbane population is also aging: in 2016 more than a quarter of the population was not participating in the workforce. This is due to a trend among retirees from southern Australian states to move to Brisbane for warm weather year-round. Owing to the high cost of inner city housing, newcomers have typically dispersed towards the urban fringes. Meanwhile, jobs are heavily concentrated in the traditional CBD. Automobile ownership is high throughout Brisbane with 94 percent of households owning a car, whereas the public transport network is considered barely ‘average’ by international standards. Coverage, frequency, and reliability are limited outside the inner city. In addition to conventional buses, Brisbane comprises rail, BRT, and ferries. Developed in the late 19th century, Brisbane’s 380 kilometre rail network consists of six electrified suburban lines extending from the CBD in a radial pattern. In the inner city, rail catchment areas are increasingly resembling TOD. The BRT system was first introduced in 2000 and comprises 25 kilometres across three radial lines. A network of river ferries (CityCats) was introduced in 1996. Ferries have helped reorient the city back to its river and have encouraged inner city densification. All public transport services are overseen and coordinated by an integrated agency (TransLink) established in 2003. Cycling is a marginal mode: only 1.5% of people cycle to work. This is due to Brisbane’s hilly topography and hot summer weather but also a very limited road infrastructure designed to protect cyclists. The most recent major transport infrastructure projects in Brisbane have included three automobile tunnels (Clem7, Airport Link, and Legacy) and one automobile bridge (Go Between Bridge). Each of these has road tolls in place as a value capture mechanism. Active travel investments include three pedestrian-and-cyclists-only bridges (Kurilpa Bride, Eleanor Schonell Bridge, and Goodwill Bridge), a successful pedestrian mall (Queen Street Mall), and several multi-use trails (Bicentennial Bikeway and Riverwalk). A bikesharing system (CityCycle) is also available since 2017.

As discussed previously, the Brisbane City Council has confirmed that unlike the other case study cities, they do not have a census of inner city parking supply although parking has been a priority focus previously with their [parking taskforce](https://www.brisbane.qld.gov.au/traffic-and-transport/parking-in-brisbane/brisbane-parking-taskforce). They do however collect and release paid on street that reveals 883 parking meters and 6,924 paid on street parking bays are known. Fortunately, the Queensland Department of Transport and Main Roads has conducted a 18% sample of the inner city surface that reveals 60,014 off street parking bays are known that include residential, commercial, and workplace parking. Combined with the Australian Bureau of Statistics’ Census of Population and Housing [datapacks]( https://www.abs.gov.au/websitedbs/d3310114.nsf/home/2016%20datapacks) (CPH), it is possible to count the number of private vehicles owned by inner city residents (i.e., the VEHD data)and the number of private vehicles arriving with inner city workers (i.e., the MTWP15 data). This combination reveals that just 1 in 4.6 private vehicles has known residential parking, and just 1 in 1.6 private vehicles arriving with workers could be parked within all other known parking. Using the City of Melbourne parking data to calculate average bay size, it is also possible to estimate there are at least 1,928 hectares of parking, which could cover 5 percent of inner city surface if laid flat.

Using the CPH accessed using the [Census TableBuilder]( https://www.abs.gov.au/websitedbs/censushome.nsf/home/tablebuilder), it is also possible to examine 236 distinct multimodal trip chains [MTWP] for inner city workers in 2011 and 2016, and summarise the complexity of these 3 mode trip chains using “upset plots” (see Kimpton [2019](https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/0308518X19890871)). For example, an overwhelming majority of inner Brisbane workers parked private vehicles in the inner city during 2011 and this majority expanded further by 2016 thus suggesting that public transport is losing appeal or that private transport is gaining appeal. The latter could be attributable to major transport infrastructure projects in including 3 automobile tunnels (i.e. Clem7, Airport Link, Legacy) and 1 automobile bridge (i.e. Go Between Bridge) that are reducing congestion and have tolls as value capture mechanisms, which suggests Brisbane motorists are willing to pay for the privilege to avoid congestion. Active transport has had just a marginal increase possibly due to Brisbane hilly geography so it is plausible that the rise of e-bikes could introduce change by the time of the 2021 CPH. Last, it is notable that parking ‘n’ riding is a popular multimodal journey into the inner city although users have remained similar at both time points.

### Inner Sydney, New South Wales, Australia

<center><img src="../data/1280px-Sydney_aerial_view_4_3_400w.jpg" width="100%"/> </center>

<center><p><b><i>Port Jackson Bay (<a href="https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=33470485"> Kozlenko</a>)</i></b></p></center>

Australia’s ‘mother city’, Sydney is located midway along the east coast of the State of New South Wales. Its spatial form fans out from Port Jackson, and is interrupted by multiple harbours, bays, and water bodies (e.g., Sydney Harbour, Middle Harbour, North Harbour, Lane Cove River, and Parramatta River). Once the landing site of the earliest European settlers, Sydney remains the economic powerhouse of the continent. It is also highly ranked globally for its economic influence. Furthermore, it is the principal destination for newly arriving migrants to Australia: 39% of the population is born overseas. The city is the most populous in Australia, though growth has been slowing down. The housing prices are among the highest in the world, comparable to London and New York. Detached, single-family houses are quite common and comprise more than half of the housing stock. This explains why residential development stretches quite far from the CBD. Sydney’s public transit network is ranked ‘poor’ by international standards. It is worse than Brisbane’s, particularly in terms of accessibility. This is, in part, attributable to the challenges of travelling around the harbours and reaching the CBD from the suburbs. (The traditional Sydney CBD is located near the shore and therefore far from the city’s geographical centre.) The city is car-oriented, though less so than Brisbane: 89% of households own an automobile. The rail network (tram and train) extends 815 kilometres, and a few segregated busways have been built, which, however, do not connect in an integrated network. A metro system (the nation’s largest infrastructure project) is currently under development. It will deliver 66 kilometres of track and 31 stations. In conjunction, the existing light rail network will be expanded. Ferry transport is also available along the bays and the Parramatta River, with all lines emanating from Circular Quay in the CBD. Cycling is even less popular than in Brisbane and Melbourne. While the weather patterns are arguably ideal for year-round cycling, investment in this mode has been minimal. At least six docked and dockless bikesharing schemes operate in different parts of Sydney, with limited success.

Also discussed previously, the City of Sydney has a small local government area relative to Brisbane City Council which makes a census of parking more feasible. Their open parking data reveals 1,365 parking meters and 20,897 paid on street parking bays are known within inner Sydney and their [FES]( https://www.cityofsydney.nsw.gov.au/surveys-case-studies-reports/floor-space-employment-survey-2017) data reveals a further 11,959 residential and 5,919 other off street parking bays are known. Combined again with the Australian Bureau of Statistics’ Census of Population and Housing [datapacks]( https://www.abs.gov.au/websitedbs/d3310114.nsf/home/2016%20datapacks) (CPH), it is possible to count the number of private vehicles owned by inner city residents (i.e., the VEHD data) and the number of private vehicles arriving with inner city workers (i.e., the MTWP15 data). This combination reveals that 1 in 5.13 private vehicles have known residential off street parking, and just 1 in 20.99 private vehicles arriving with workers could be parked within all other known parking. Using the City of Melbourne parking data again to calculate average bay size, it is also possible to estimate there are at least 50,132 hectares of parking, which could cover 5 percent of inner city surface if laid flat.

Using the CPH accessed using the [Census TableBuilder]( https://www.abs.gov.au/websitedbs/censushome.nsf/home/tablebuilder), it is again possible to examine the 236 distinct multimodal trip chains [MTWP] for inner city workers in 2011 and 2016, and summarise the complexity of these 3 mode trip chains using “upset plots” (see Kimpton [2019](https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/0308518X19890871)). For example, a small majority of inner Sydney workers parked their private vehicles in the inner city during 2011 but the majority became train journeys in 2016, which suggests effective TOD policies. Active transport has gained considerable popularity for reaching inner Sydney relative to inner Brisbane, and train ridership has had a remarkable 64% increase.  This suggests that [projects](https://www.transport.nsw.gov.au/sites/default/files/media/documents/2017/long-term-transport-master-plan-annual-update-2014.pdf) including the North West Rail Link and the South West Rail Link that improve coverage, and the Northern Sydney Freight Corridor that has removed a portion of freight trains are proving effective at increasing the appeal of rail travel.

### Inner Melbourne, Victoria, Australia

<center><img src="../data/melbourne CBD and port panorama website_4_3_400w.jpg" width="100%"/> </center>

<center><p><b><i>Port Phillip Bay (<a href="https://population.org.au/articles/2019-06-08/aerial-photos-melbournes-growth-2018">Fry</a>)</i></b></p></center>

Melbourne, Australia’s cultural capital, is located midway along the south coast of the State of Victoria. Its spatial form wraps around Port Phillip Bay. Since the gold rush of the 1850s, Melbourne has remained one of the world’s wealthiest cities and often ranks as one of the most liveable cities globally. While its population is only slightly behind Sydney, its recent growth exceeds Sydney’s. Hence, Melbourne is poised to soon become Australia’s most populous city. It is, however, more compact than both Sydney and Brisbane. The public transport network ranks below average by global standards – and is considered worse than the public transport on offer in Brisbane and Sydney, relative to the city’s size and importance. Melbourne comprises an iconic 250-kilometre tram network, which is still the largest in the world. It managed to retain its trams at the time when other large Australian cities removed their rail tracks to make space for automobiles. While trams have priority on the road, they can become trapped in traffic congestion, same as private automobiles, which may explain the city’s poor global ranking. Another weakness of Melbourne’s transport system is its road design, which requires drivers to frequently change lanes and take ‘hook turns’ to navigate around trams. This exacerbates congestion. Similar to Sydney, Melbourne is currently developing a cross-city metro system (Metrotunnel), which will bypass most inner city stations. Cycling only slightly more popular than in Brisbane. A docked bikesharing scheme (Melbourne Bike Share) was in operation between 2010 and 2019. A dockless scheme (oBikes) was trialled in 2018 but it proved unsuccessful.

Also discussed previously, the City of Melbourne as well as the City of Sydney have a small local government areas relative to Brisbane City Council which makes a census of parking more feasible. Their open parking data reveals that 23,310 on-street parking bays are known and available as polygonal data for examining bay size. Further, 2,928 of these on street parking bays are managed by 1,962 parking meters and 3,111 by on street sensors that connect to a smart phone application and enable motorists to pay by the minute rather than their predicted duration. Their [CLUE](https://www.melbourne.vic.gov.au/about-melbourne/research-and-statistics/city-economy/census-land-use-employment/Pages/clue.aspx) data reveals a further 49,371 residential off street parking bays and 143,740 other off street parking bays are known, and all these parking data. Combined once more with the Australian Bureau of Statistics’ Census of Population and Housing [datapacks]( https://www.abs.gov.au/websitedbs/d3310114.nsf/home/2016%20datapacks) (CPH), it is possible to count the number of private vehicles owned by inner city residents (i.e., the VEHD data) and the number of private vehicles arriving with inner city workers (i.e., the MTWP15 data). This combination reveals that there are 1.43 (i.e. 1/0.7) residential parking bays known each private vehicle owned thus suggesting a residential parking oversupply. Also, there are 1.05 private vehicles arriving with inner Melbourne workers for each other off street parking bay known thus suggesting either an incomplete census or a classification error between private and other parking. Last, it is possible to provide a relatively accurate estimate of parking area for Melbourne given that the on street parking is available as polygons and the CLUE data include floor space. In sum, inner Melbourne has 207.83 hectares of residential parking, 157.28 hectares of other off-street parking known, and 33.95 hectares of on street parking known, which cumulatively could cover 11% of inner Melbourne if laid flat which is similar to the typical US city 10% estimate (Scharnhorst, [2018](https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/4598972-RIHA-Parking-Report)).

Using the CPH accessed using the [Census TableBuilder]( https://www.abs.gov.au/websitedbs/censushome.nsf/home/tablebuilder), it is once more possible to examine the 236 distinct multimodal trip chains [MTWP] for inner city workers in 2011 and 2016, and summarise the complexity of these 3 mode trip chains using “upset plots” (see Kimpton [2019](https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/0308518X19890871)). For example, the gap is closing between inner Melbourne workers parking their private vehicles in the inner city and other modal choices but it is also notable that bicycle popularity has slid behind bus popularity. Similar to Sydney, the declining popularity in driving is largely attributable to a 58% rise in rail ridership, which could be attributable to [projects]( https://www.ptv.vic.gov.au/assets/default-site/footer/legal-and-policies/growing-our-rail-network-2018-2025/5290c0d0b4/PTV_Network-Development-Plan_Metropolitan-Rail_Overview_2016update.pdf) such as the Regional Rail Link that has extended the rail network 47.5 kilometres west and upgrades such as the Cranbourne Line that raises the rail line above traffic crossings. Further, this uptake in rail travel could be a welcoming sign for the Melbourne Metro Tunnel project that is becoming tarnished by [budgetary blowouts]( https://www.abc.net.au/news/2020-12-11/metro-tunnel-budget-blows-out-by-more-than-2-billion/12974940) and [delays](https://www.theage.com.au/national/victoria/metro-tunnel-digging-running-seven-months-late-20201115-p56epy.html).

### Visitor Purpose

```{r purpose}
df1 <- intercept_survey %>%
  transmute(day,
            transport = tolower(mode),
            transport = factor(transport, levels = c("active", "public", "private")),
            ans_q5_passing_through = ifelse(ans_q5_passing_through == "Yes", 1, 0),
            ans_q5_working = ifelse(ans_q5_working == "Yes", 1, 0),
            ans_q5_shopping = ifelse(ans_q5_shopping == "Yes", 1, 0),
            ans_q5_dining = ifelse(ans_q5_dining == "Yes", 1, 0),
            ans_q5_visiting = ifelse(ans_q5_visiting == "Yes", 1, 0),
            total = 1) %>% 
  group_by(day, transport) %>% 
  summarise(ans_q5_passing_through = sum(ans_q5_passing_through),
            ans_q5_working = sum(ans_q5_working),
            ans_q5_shopping = sum(ans_q5_shopping),
            ans_q5_dining = sum(ans_q5_dining),
            ans_q5_visiting = sum(ans_q5_visiting),
            total = sum(total)) %>%
  mutate(ans_q5_passing_through = ans_q5_passing_through/total,
         ans_q5_working = ans_q5_working/total,
         ans_q5_shopping = ans_q5_shopping/total,
         ans_q5_dining = ans_q5_dining/total,
         ans_q5_visiting = ans_q5_visiting/total) %>%
  gather(var, val, ans_q5_passing_through:ans_q5_visiting) %>%
  mutate(var = ifelse(var == "ans_q5_passing_through", "passing through",
                      ifelse(var == "ans_q5_working", "working",
                             ifelse(var == "ans_q5_shopping", "shopping",
                                    ifelse(var == "ans_q5_dining", "dining", "services")))),
         temp = round(val * 100,1),
         label = paste0(transport, "\n", temp, "%"))

p1 <- ggplot(df1, aes(x=transport, y = temp, fill = transport,
                      text = paste0(var, " is the visit purpose for ", temp, "% of ", transport," transport visitors"))) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity",  colour = "black") +
  theme_light() +
  facet_grid(var ~ day) +
  theme(legend.position = "none") + 
  scale_fill_manual(values= uq_palette) +
  ylab("") +
  xlab("") +
  ylim(0,80) +
  guides(fill=FALSE)

ggplotly(p1, tooltip = 'text')
```

```{r bubbles_test}
f <- list(
  family = "Arial",
  size = 15,
  color = "black"
)

  title = "Perceived arriving by car [%]",
  titlefont = f

df1 <- rbind(df1 %>% 
               mutate(data = "respondent"),
             df1 %>%
               group_by(transport, label, day) %>%
               summarise(km = round(mean(km, na.rm = TRUE), 1),
                         mins = round(mean(mins, na.rm = TRUE), 1),
                         aud = round(mean(aud, na.rm = TRUE), 1),
                         percent = round(mean(percent, na.rm = TRUE), 1)) %>%
               ungroup() %>% 
               mutate(data = "mean")) %>% 
  mutate(data = factor(data, levels = c("respondent", "mean")),
         random = runif(1:n(), min = -0.4, max = 0.4),
         transport = ifelse(data == "mean", transport, transport + random))

p1 <- ggplot(df1, aes(x= transport, y=percent, color = label, shape = data, order = data,
                      text = paste('data: ', data, '\n',
```
