### Parking Turnover

```{r parking_period}
f <- list(
  family = "Arial",
  size = 15,
  color = "black"
)
y <- list(
  title = "Parking [bay]",
  titlefont = f
)

df1 <- licence_plates_df %>%
  mutate(id = paste(parking_bay, licence_plate, sep = "_"),
         timestamp = ymd_hms(timestamp),
         day = wday(timestamp,label = TRUE, abbr = FALSE)) %>%
  arrange(timestamp, day) %>% 
  group_by(id) %>% 
  summarise(start = first(timestamp),
            end = last(timestamp),
            bay = first(parking_bay),
            sign = last(sign_tidy),
            start_day = first(day),
            last_day = last(day)) %>% 
  ungroup() %>%
  filter(start_day == last_day,
         sign != "Loading Zone") %>%
  transmute(start, end, bay, sign,
            day = ordered(as.character(start_day), levels = c("Wednesday", "Saturday")), start_time = paste0(hour(start),":", sprintf("%02d", minute(start))),
            end_time = paste0(hour(end),":", sprintf("%02d", minute(end))))

p1 <- ggplot(df1, aes(x= end, y=bay, colour=sign)) +
  geom_segment(aes(xend = start, yend = bay,
                   text = paste('first recorded: ', start_time, '\n',
                                 'last recorded: ', end_time, '\n',
                                 'sign at departure: ', sign, '\n')), size = 1) +
  geom_point(data=df1, aes(x = end, y = bay,
                           text = paste('last recorded: ', end_time, '\n',
                                        'sign at departure: ', sign, '\n')), size =1.5, shape = 21, fill = "white") +
  geom_point(data=df1, aes(x = start, y = bay,
                           text = paste('first recorded: ', start_time, '\n',
                                        'sign at departure: ', sign, '\n')), size =1.5, shape = 19) +
  scale_colour_manual(values= uq_palette_8, name = "Parking restriction") +
  facet_wrap(. ~ day, shrink = TRUE, scales = "free_x") +
  theme_light() +
  xlab("Time [15min increments]") +
  theme(axis.title.y=element_blank(), axis.text.y = element_blank())
  
ggplotly(p1, tooltip = 'text') %>%
  plotly::layout(yaxis = y)
```

### Parking Catchment

```{r parking_cachement}
f <- list(
  family = "Arial",
  size = 15,
  color = "black"
)
y <- list(
  title = "Private Transport [%]",
  titlefont = f
)

df1 <- licence_plates_dist %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  mutate(day,
         km = cut(network_km,
                  breaks = c(0, 2, 4, 8, 16, 32, 64, 2000),
                  labels = c("< 2",
                             "< 4",
                             "< 8",
                             "< 16",
                             "< 32",
                             "< 64",
                             ">= 64"),
                  right = F),
         duration) %>% 
  drop_na(km) %>% 
  group_by(day, km) %>% 
  summarise(n = n())

df1 <- df1 %>% 
  group_by(day) %>% 
  summarise(total = sum(n)) %>% 
  left_join(df1, by = "day") %>% 
  mutate(percent = round(n/total*100))

p1 <- ggplot(df1, aes(x= km, y= percent,  text = paste0(percent, "% of private transport parked along \nBoundary St are registered ", km, "km away"))) + 
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = uq_palette[3], colour = "black") +
  facet_wrap(. ~ day) +
  theme_light() +
  xlab("Network distance [km]") +
  theme(axis.title.y=element_blank())

ggplotly(p1, tooltip = 'text') %>%
  plotly::layout(yaxis = y)
```

### West End, Queensland, Australia

<center><img src="../data/Westendboundary.jpg" width="100%"/> </center>

<center><p><b><i>Boundary Street, West End (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Westendboundary.jpg">Wikimedia</a>)</i></b></p></center>

West End, a Brisbane inner city suburb, has multiple characteristics that make it an interesting case study in terms of parking. For instance, its population (9,500 residents) is wealthier and better educated relative to other suburbs throughout Brisbane, Queensland, and Australia on the whole (e.g. 46% of have a bachelor degree or higher compared to 22-23% in other suburbs). The suburb is located on a river peninsula with few entry and exit routes. The resultant traffic congestion may explain why this suburb has the highest rates of walking and cycling to work in Brisbane (e.g. 20% of workers reach their workplaces by active transport thus four times the Brisbane average). A compact land-use pattern and a location within two kilometres of the CBD are other explanations for high levels of active travel in this suburb. The local housing stock is also unique: it grew by nearly 50% in the last decade, which is more than twice the Brisbane average. In particular, the multifamily housing stock grew eleven times the Brisbane average. In addition, parking maximums (or caps) rather than traditional parking minimums apply for new residential development. This policy was predicated on public transport improvements, which have so far not materialized. This has left many residents parking-restricted yet auto-dependent or stranded along a redeveloped industrial riverfront. In combination, these characteristics have turned local parking supply into a hotly contested issue (Pojani and Sipe [2020](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/17549175.2020.1762112)).

<button class="accordion">Public Forum Narratives</button>
<div class="panel">
<p></p>

To examine existing and emerging narratives around parking, a public forum entitled ‘Should we replace street parking with bike lanes?’ was held in February 2018 in West End. Local residents and businesses owners were invited to publicly comment on a proposal to replace several corridors of on-street parking with protected bicycle lines to improve mobility and relieve auto-dependence. The forum lasted about four hours and 60 people attended. Their demographic details were not recorded, but participants were all adults. Public opinions were collected during a ‘question and answer’ session with the invited keynote speakers, and during roundtable discussions that followed. The forum proceedings were recorded and transcribed. In addition, the authors moderated roundtable discussions and took written notes of those discussions, which were also transcribed. All these qualitative data were collated within a single spreadsheet. The comments were then thematically coded according to an a priori analytical framework that comprises ‘parking supply’ and ‘parking demand’. This framework was constructed upon a thorough review of the available literature on parking issues.

The analysis revealed two main opposing storylines. The first has been in existence for several decades and it follows a predictable narrative arc: initial statement of problem > introduction of protagonists/antagonists > rising action period > crisis or climax > denouement or resolution. The ‘problem’ in this storyline is that free parking is the birthright of the Australian people. Government officials and developers are ‘villains’ attempting to forcibly take this birthright away. The ‘protagonists’ are the people who organise and resist (the ‘crisis’), and attempt to restore peace (the ‘denouement’) by protecting the existing parking supply and demanding more parking. This narrative echoes the predict-and-provide (or predict-and-require) paradigm that has dominated parking supply for at least fifty years. Given the large volume of parking-related complaints received by Brisbane City Council (about 128,000 per year, or 9% of all complaints), it is clear that this widely shared narrative.

As socio-economic and technological changes take hold in Australian cities, and the effects of climate change are felt in a major way, a second narrative is emerging, which again follows a standard narrative arc. The ‘problem’ in this version is ensuring urban liveability and protecting sustainability. The ‘villains’ are stubborn and polluting motorists, whereas the people who relocate to inner cities and other TOD zones, and switch to active and public modes of transport are the ‘protagonists’. By reclaiming space wasted on parking which disrupts the paths of pedestrians and cyclists (the ‘climax’), these protagonists attempt to restore peace (reach the ‘denouement’). Contemporary planners often align with the latter narrative. Indeed it may be the stories that planners tell of future cities that entice the public to consider alternative narratives. Due to the qualitative nature of this study, we cannot measure how prevalent the second storyline is. Nonetheless, its emergence is welcome as it that bodes well for advocates of parking demand management, urban liveability, and sustainability.

That is not to say that the concerns raised by those espousing the conventional narrative are not legitimate. For example, parking restrictions may greatly inconvenience traders (e.g., contractors, plumbers, electricians, or other service providers), who need to transport heavy tools for their work. This is a major issue, which may potentially affect the livelihoods and lifestyles of thousands, given that contemporary urban economies, in the West at least, are heavily or entirely service-based. With regards to retail, this is being gradually replaced by e-commerce but this shift does not solve the urban freight parking problem. E-commerce also requires parking access – perhaps more so than traditional retail. Recent evidence suggests that, with more home-delivery, micro-mobility, and ride-hailing providers entering the digital marketplace, competition for the physical street curb is rising rather than declining. Equity concerns need addressing too. People living in areas with inadequate transit service, as well as those who are elderly or physically impaired, are necessarily car-dependent, and eliminating parking may disadvantage them in a major way. Finally, there is no guarantee that any centrally located land that is freed up where parking maximums apply will be used for socially beneficial land-uses such as affordable housing.

As with all good stories, the narratives presented in this article simplify a complex reality to its essence so as to render it accessible and memorable – as claimed by the advocates of storytelling in planning. Naturally, the picture on the ground is much more nuanced – involving many more characters, subplots, and twists. Then, what is the practical value of these findings to planners and policy makers? How can these findings be put into use? We claim that the emerging parking narrative maps a possible path for what the 2020s could look like in terms of mobility and land-use - if we decide to take collective action. In an increasingly urban world, we also need to tell a new story about our cities.

See Pojani and Sipe ([2020](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/17549175.2020.1762112)) for further reading.

</div>

<button class="accordion">Visitor Intercept Survey</button>
<div class="panel">
<p></p>

Drawing upon the discussions with West End traders and residents during the public forum, an intercept survey was developed to reveal: how visitors reach Boundary Street; why this modal choice is preferred; where they reside; their employment status and profession; the purpose(s) of their visit; how much they are spending; their age and gender; and how they perceive other visitors are reaching Boundary Street. Further, when they were surveyed between 7am and 9pm were recorded examining how visits vary throughout the day, and whether it was Wednesday the 7th of October or Saturday the 10th of October given that public forum participants indicated that parking is a particularly contentious issue on Saturdays when large numbers visit the nearby [Davies Park Markets](https://daviesparkmarket.com.au/).

As to be expected, Boundary Street visitors arriving by active transport (i.e. walking or cycling) on a weekday travelled 1.4 kilometres on average relative to 5.5 for those arriving by public transport (i.e. multimodal travel that includes, busses, trains, or a ferry), 8.2 kilometres for those arriving by private transport (i.e. car, motorbike, taxi or Uber). Interestingly, some active transport visitors travelled 19 kilometres to Boundary Street yet most still resided within the West End peninsular. Contrasting Wednesday to Saturday also revealed novel insights including that both active and public transport visitors were traveling shorter distances on average on Saturdays—0.9 and 3.8 kilometres respectively—while the average distance for private transport visitors more than doubled to 19.7 kilometres in part attributable to visitors driving 123 kilometres to visit Boundary Street on a Saturday.

Contrasting the duration of visitor stays by modal choice and day reveals that active transport visitors remain 88.9 minutes on average on Wednesdays but longer at 114.3 minutes on average on Saturdays. In contrast, public transport visitors remain 183.1 minutes on average on Wednesdays but shorter at 130.0 minutes on Saturdays. Similar to active transport visitors, private transport visitors stay for longer on average on Saturdays relative to Wednesdays (i.e. 121.3 and 145.5 minutes respectively). Skewness is a further similarity between active and private transport given that the majority are visiting for shorter periods, while there is greater variation between public transport visitors on both days.

Unlike the perceptions of traders revealed during the public forum, average visitor spending on Wednesdays was similar for all transport modes with given that active transport visitors spend AUD24.10 on average, public transport visitors AUD24.20, and private transport visitors AUD22.60. On Saturdays, visitor spending near doubled with active transport visitors spending AUD40.50 on average and public transport visitors AUD43.10, while private transport visitors spending more than tripled at AUD68.90 on average. This later finding suggests that parking availability is particularly critical for traders during Saturdays.

Given that perceptions of how visitors reach Boundary Street varied considerably between interest groups during the public forum, these perceptions are contrasted by modal choice and day. While private transport visitors perceive that greater numbers of Boundary Street visitors are arriving by car at 47.3% on average, active and public transport visitors share similar perceptions at 46.6% and 45.7% respectively, and it is notable that private transport visitors have a bimodal distribution thus suggesting that there could be a distinction within this grouping. Greater variation occurs on Saturday when public transport visitors perceive that 58.3% of other Boundary Street visitors are arriving by car, which potentially explains their decision to use public rather than private transport on this day.

The purpose for visiting Boundary Street also reveals novel findings. For instance, only 6.2% of public transport visitors were visiting Boundary Street for dining on Wednesday relative to 25.0% of active transport and 36.7% of private transport visitors. By Saturday, there was a similar increase across all travel modes with 25.0% of public transport visitors, 59.1% of active transport visitors, and 60.7% of private transport visitors dining along Boundary Street. Visitors stopping at Boundary Street on their way to somewhere else ranged between 10.0% to 12.5% across all three transport modes, and the only notable distinction between days was that no private transport visitors indicated that they were passing through on Saturday thus suggesting that Boundary Street was their final destination for this visit. On Wednesday, 6.7% of active transport visitors, 12.5% of public transport visitors, and 26.7% of active transport visitors were at Boundary Street to access services, and these figures all dropped to 5.4% or less by Saturday. Interestingly, just 13.3% of private transport visitors arrived for shopping on Wednesday, while 30.0% of active transport and 43.8% of public transport visitors arrived for this purpose. By Saturday, this figure increased to 31.8% or more across the three modes suggesting there is less variation on Saturdays and therefore parking availability has less impact on this day. Amongst the three modes, public transport visitors were the most likely to include working amongst their purposes for visiting Boundary St with 31.2% on Wednesday and 12.5% by Saturday. In sum, the clearest distinction between modal choices was visitors are unlikely to arrive by public transport when they intend to dine, and that the remaining purposes are similar across active and private transport visitors thus parking could be a weaker determinant than previously assumed. 

<p></p>
</div>

<button class="accordion">On Street Parking Observation Survey</button>
<div class="panel">
<p></p>

During the public forum, a common perception amongst West End traders was that an undersupply of on street parking was responsible for declining trade, and that local residents were shopping in other suburbs to avoid extended periods of cruising for parking. Another common perception amongst the traders was that this limited parking supply was being exhausted for extended periods by neighbouring yet downstream suburbs treating West End as an informal park `n’ ride given that there are frequent public transport services travelling along a relatively direct route towards the Brisbane CBD. As such, an observation survey was developed to record car licence plates in 15 minute intervals from 7am until 9pm on Wednesday the 7th of October and Saturday the 10th of October. To keep the anonymity of the vehicle owners, a lookup table was generated for the Department of Transport and Main Roads that included Queensland *postcodes* and the *network distance* from Boundary Street to the centroid of the postcode area in question. In turn, this department looked up the postcodes associated with the licence plates and returned just the *licence plate* and the *network distance* so that all that could be determined about the vehicle owners is the distance they traveled to Boundary Street, their time of arrival and departure, and the parking restrictions in place.

For capturing *parking demand*, 54 on street parking bays observed. Parking demand peaked at 18:15 on Wednesday by reaching 70% of maximum capacity, and at 21:15 on Saturday by reaching 81% of maximum capacity. Across the Wednesday, parking demand typically remained below 50% of parking capacity except from 10:45 until 13:45, and after 18:15 thus suggesting dining is a key influence. In contrast, parking demand typically remained above 50% of parking capacity on Saturday from 7:30 onwards and only dipping below from 16:30 until 17:00 thus suggesting that dining again has a key influence over parking demand, and that breakfast dining exerts a stronger influence on Saturdays. Notably, parking demand never reached parking capacity and only reached 80% briefly on Saturday, which is particularly interesting threshold given *dynamic parking systems* (e.g., SFPark) are typically calibrated to ensure that 20% of parking on a street remains vacant to minimise cruising for parking. 

For observing *parking turnover*, a barbell graph was used where a solid circle indicates a new licence plate within a parking bay and an solid circle indicates the last recording of a licence plate. 27 out of 242 vehicles parked at a ¼P sign remained longer than 15minutes on Wednesday with one remaining for 4.5 hours, and 8 out of 40 on Saturday with one vehicle remaining for 2.5 hours. While 13 out of 55 vehicles parked where P10 bays were remained present for more than 15minutes on Wednesday and 18 out of 57 on Saturday, it is notable that turnover occurred at a higher rate at these unmetered bays and the longest stay on Wednesday was 45minutes on Wednesday and 1hour on Saturday thus suggesting these unmetered P10 restrictions are proving more effective than the metered ¼P restrictions as in terms of increasing parking turnover. Also, 13 out of 56 vehicles parked at unmetered 1/2P signs on Wednesday remained at least 45minutes and 39 out of 153 on Saturday so while these findings suggest these signs are relatively ineffective for encouraging short stays and high parking turnover, it is notable that these signs only apply outside of the general workday period thus could represent distinct purposes for visits such as primarily visiting for dining.

Next examining parking bays with a 2hour maximum stay, 10 out of 236 parked at meters on Wednesday remained beyond the 2hours with one instance first observed at 7am and remained for 7.5 hours, and 6 out of 40 on Saturday with one instance first observed at 7am and remained until 10hours. Like the unmetered 1/P restriction, the unmetered 2P restriction was in place outside of the general workday with 5 out of 64 remaining parked beyond the maximum stay period on Wednesday with the longest remaining from 6pm until the last recording at 8:45pm, and 16 out of 172 on Saturday with the longest remaining 8.5hours. In contrast to the shorter stay parking restrictions, there is less distinction between metered and unmetered parking regarding parking turnover and exceeding the maximum duration.  

To interpret *parking catchments* areas as discussed during the pubic forum, it is important to distinguish the *local community* apart from *extra-local visitors*. As such, those residing within 2km of Boundary Street are defined as members of the local community given that this range encloses the West End peninsular. Notably, 26% of the parked vehicles on Wednesday and 28% on Saturday were owned by members of this local community. Although those attending public forum indicated that their parking was being exhausted by members of neighbouring and downstream suburbs such Dutton Park and Annerley treating their suburb as an informal park `n’ ride, this is unlikely to be the case given that just 6% on Wednesday and 4% on Saturday resided within 2 to 4 kilometres of Boundary Street, which includes these areas. Instead, community outsiders were typically driving between 8 to 32 km to reach Boundary Street. This range encloses the greater metropolitan area, and spans past the coast in the east and the City of Logan in the south, and almost reaches the cities of Ipswich in the West and Redcliff in the North. Last, it is notable that while parking demand increased on Saturday, the catchment areas were similar for Wednesday and Saturday thus suggesting a similar profile of visitors on weekdays and weekends. 

<p></p>
</div>
